(cutlery tapping)
(egg cracking)
(sizzling)
(upbeat music)
- Hello, and welcome to Sorted Food.
Now sit down,

strap yourself in, because
we have a highly opinionated

bespectacled chef in the hot
seat today reviewing some

potentially pretentious
ingredients with one of two
incredibly good-looking, handsome,
but yet also very down to earth normals.

- Oh, I get it. You're
switching in and out.
- Yeah, yeah.
- Oh, yeah, yeah.
- Ooh.
- Uh, bacon wrapped potatoes with some
sour cream and chives?

- I think what you'll find is
the food team have called this
bacon wrapped potatoes with a nice dip.
I've inquired further, the nice dip
is sour cream and mustard.

- Straight off, it doesn't
look very pretentious at all.
- [Jamie] Have a sniff, have a taste.

Let me know if you can work
out what you think might be
potentially pretentious about this.
- Lovely mustard dip.

Well, it's going to be
the potato or the bacon.
I'm going to say the bacon looks, um.
- Quality.
- Yeah.

- Boys, what you have in
front of you is Iberico bacon.
Bacon, but better.

So, Iberico pork is known for
it's juicy and tender meat.
So, what better way to try Iberico
than in a delicious thick rasher of bacon?
The abundance of fat from the Iberico pork
elevates this bacon to a whole new level,
whilst it melts in the pan.

This is a must for bacon
and Iberico lovers.

- Can I just double
check? What is Iberico?
Is it, is it a pig, a place, or a process?
- Yes.
- Good, good chat.
(laughs)
- So, Iberico pork comes from
the distinctive black Iberico pig.

So it's native to areas
of Portugal and to Spain,

the pigs eat diet mainly
of acorns, very natural.
They are allowed to roam.

They are the best quality pigs
that you could really hope to

find, that are cared for in
the most loving way possible,
and then are absolutely delicious to eat.

- I can absolutely
taste the fat is better,

and it is mostly fat, and
it is that wonderful fat.
It is exceptional.
- Yeah.
- Ooh! Slappy slap slap.

- [Jamie] So that's the
packet. That's how it comes.
We got this from Fine Food Specialist.

They source theirs from
a family run company,
Juan Pedro Domecq,
they've been doing this for two centuries.
- I can't think of many places where

a slice of bacon is going
to be bettered by this,

if the price is as high as I
imagine it has to be given the
process and the rules around Iberico.
- So speaking of price,
how much do you think we paid for
250 gramme packets of the Iberico bacon?

Bearing in mind, like, top
supermarket brand levels,

you're looking at sort of,
£3, £3.50 for 250 grammes.
- If that was six quid, I'd buy that.
I'd buy that.

I'd buy it because I think it
was worth the special treat,
- Higher.
- But it's gonna be more like 20.
- I reckon it's £2 a slice. £10.
- Ebbers is on the money, £9.95.
- Wrapped around spuds, on a fry up with

some mushrooms and
tomatoes, beans toast, egg.
It doesn't need Aberico.

The Aberico flavour should
be savoured almost as is.
And I can't think of where you'd put that.
- I'm kind of okay with it.

I don't think I would
pay that money for it,

because I think I'm
happy with just normal,
really good quality bacon.

- I suppose there's only
one question left to ask,
Iberico bacon, pretentious or not?
- No, it delivers everything that it says.
- It's not pretentious.

It just doesn't have
a place on the fry up.
- Look how filthy your fingers are.
- I know, I told you.

- That is impressive.
- Greased up.
- Number two?

Barry, it must be your
turn to lift the cloche.
- It is. Yeah? Yeah?
- Give it a lift.
- [Barry] Yeah.
Yes!
Whoa, whoa, whoa.

- It's got the croissant golden
colour and swirl and layers,
but it's in a shape of a die.
I want to,

I want to see a cross section
of this beast, may we?
- You mean a croiss-section?!
(they laugh)

- It looks like they've taken
six croissants and squished it

together. But on the other
side is look like they are one.
- [Ebbers] Jamie, what is this?
- Boys, this is croissant cube bread

created by a Swedish baker
named Bedros Kabranian.

He's actually part of the
Swedish National pastry team.
Essentially, he wanted to give a new shape
to the iconic French breakfast bread.
Didn't imagine for a second

how big a ruckus this would
cause on social media when he
started promoting it.
- And don't get me wrong,
'cause I'm sure he's a better baker
than all of us put together.

However, the very name
croissant means crescent,
it is literally named after its shape.

- I like croissants when
they're freshly baked,

and they're like, crispy on the
outside, soft in the middle.
So I've always thought,
could you put a croissant in a toaster?
Now I think you could.

- Would you like to see what
our food team have invented?

- I don't, I don't, I know it's
gonna be really bad for me.

Huh. What is, Jamie, did
you offend somebody in the,
in the food team?
- What we have in front of us is a-
- Monstrosity!
- [Jamie] Is a bread and butter pudding,

but built as a cube, so that
the layers of thick custard in

between toasted bread with a
raisin jam. Posh comfort food.
- This, this I'm down for.
- Yeah.

And then we also have the
ultimate cheese toasty with

multiple cheeses for that
incredible cheese pull.
- I'm trying to like, be conscious of
my cholesterol intake, but.

- Yeah, well just don't have
any for the next three weeks.
You'll be fine.
- Yin and yang.
- Tell my family I love them.
- Oh, he kissed that.
- [Barry] There's a chance

there's more cheese than
bread in that toasty.
- [Ebbers] Yes.
- No, too much. Too far.

- [Jamie] So this is a
bread and butter pudding
built as a cube,
so layers of thick custard
in between toasted bread with a raisin jam
bread and butter pudding in itself.
- Okay, so, right, this is delicious,

but what's stopping you just
doing the exact same thing with
normal croissants?
- Tessellation.
- Oh, god.
(laughs)
- This does make more sense to me,
for some reason, as a dessert.
And I can't, I can't tell you for why.

I think it is just the
excessive cheese there
makes it almost inedible.

Whereas this is actually
surprisingly tasty and light, and
you actually get the crunch and the gooey,
and it soaks it up.
- Does it add anything over and above
a standard brioche loaf?

- Yeah, because if I'm, brioche
is just buttery and sweet,
this is so textured and so light inside,

and we have a really
crispy outside as well.

In fact, it's crispier than
other normal croissants,

because you've got more
of a solid surface area.
What are you doing?
(laughs)

- I'm providing the
audio experience whilst

you explain how much you
love the crispy flakiness.
- Weird, though, isn't it?
- It's teamwork.
- Have a little scratch.
(laughs)

- You do have better edges and
more flakiness around there.
Although I think you lose some of the
elegance of a croissant.

- So we sourced this from a
place called The Gourmet Market.
Like the Cronut,

these bakeries have got
lines around the corner,
they're selling out of them.
They can't make them quick enough.
So this really is a thing.
How much do you think we paid for
that croissant cube loaf?
- I'm going under that it's £7.50.
- And do you know what,
you know when you're the one that gets
sent to the local boulangerie
to pick up croissants for the family,

and if you're not very careful,
by the time you get home,
a few of them are squashed and crushed?

At least you could put a couple
of these next to each other.
And on top of each other in your basket,
on the front of the bike and you're home,
no damage done. Practical.
- What fairytale are you living in?!
(laughs)
- Um, do you know what? £6.50, it's fun,
I think you'd buy it. You'd do it once,
you'd find out how to play with it.

I think you might stick to
regular croissants after that.
Maybe I'm wrong.
- Croissant cube load, pretentious or not?

- Ooh. A little bit, but
it's not pretentious.

- Now I've had time to digest
it, not this, but this,
not pretentious. Kind of cool.

- This is going to take a
while to digest, I promise you.
- Please, Jamie, lift the cloche.
- Ooh!
- That is beautiful.
- Fancy, hey?

So in front of you,
you have a Chawanmushi,
which is a Japanese steamed,

savoury custard with some
soy marinated seafood in it.

- Could you just pronounce
the name of the dish?

You said it so quickly?
I almost didn't hear.
- You know what, stuff it.
Chawanmushi.
- I don't know if you're right or wrong.
- Yeah.
And the pretentious ingredient in question

is in front of you as well,
which is the soy sauce.
Please, dig in.
- Wow.
Wow.
- Whoa.
- Wow.
- Whoa.
(laughs)
- That's phenomenal.
- Do you want to try it in the dish?
- It's got a wonderful wobbling set on it.
Cheers.
- Cheers.

- Firstly, what are you
expecting from soy sauce?

- I always just associate
soy sauce as a seasoning.
So one part of many things, okay.
- Triangle.
(laughs)
- With a number of other condiments,

and together they season
and elevate a dish.
I think when it's more the focus

and when you try on its own,
it's completely stand out.

- [Barry] That's the soy
sauce that we use here

in the studio fairly regularly,
a fairly standard soy.

So just as a comparison,
side-by-side. Okay.
- It's harsh. Harsh on the tongue.
- Okay.
- [Jamie] The viscosity is very different.

- [Ebbers] You can literally
same, same, volume in the dish.
You can see through it.

- [Barry] This is Kamibashi
soy sauce, five years old.
It originated in Japan.

It's a soy sauce that is aged
in cedar barrels for five

years to give it it's well
balanced, salty taste.

This is the perfect ingredient
to use in asian cooking,

or on its own to drizzle
over sashimi sushi.

- Ultimately, like with
the previous ingredient,
you're buying into centuries of tradition

and process, and respect
for how a product gets
to where it is. And you're paying,

therefore, not just for
the process of fermenting,
but then for ageing.
- I can't imagine using that in like,
a stir fry midweek or something like that.

But, if we were to go to
the effort of making sushi,
or buying really good quality sushi,
or sashimi or something like that,
if that feels like the right place for it.
- Let's talk money.

So bearing in mind the flavour
and balance of this soy from

Kamibashi relies on the exact
replication of the process

250 years old, and diligently
overseen by the Okada family,
right up to the 17th generation of today.
The standard soy sauce in front of you,
for 200ml bottle is £2.50.
What do you reckon this one is?
- I would pay,
£25 for that bottle, 10 times the price.

- I think it's twice
that, I think it's £50.
I'm going to say £50.
- Interesting.
Could you justify £31.95?
- That doesn't surprise me.
It's not hugely more than I thought,
less than you thought.
- It's Less than I thought,

it doesn't mean I'll
be prepared to pay it.
- Again, just like the bacon,
its application is so different from

perhaps the, like the staple
midweek ingredients that

we associate bacon and soy
sauce to be a part of our,
pretty much, everyday cooking.
- But that is a spectacular bottle of,
- Soy sauce.
- Yeah.

- Alright then. So is
it pretentious or not?

- We said at the start,
sometimes it's about the vocab

and the language around the
marketing and the packaging,

but I don't know how else
you would explain this if it

wasn't for listing off
the numbers of years,

the years of fermentation and
ageing and cedar and the family
name is important, the tradition.

So I don't think it's
pretentious, I think it's factual.
I just think it's such quality,
that we don't get it anywhere else.

- This one could be
interesting boys. Men, please.
Lift the cloche.
(chicken clucks)
- Is it a chicken Barry?
- Well done, Jamie! 10 points!
- Pou-let affines.
- Pou-lay.
Poulet.
- Pou-let.
- Poulet.

- These are La Cour
D'armoise Poulette Affinee,

these chickens have been
favourite in France's
three-star Michelin restaurants,

the chickens hens and Guinea
fowls from Patis Farm,
are renowned for the exceptional quality
and incredible taste.

- [Jamie] So this is
Michelin star chicken?
- [Barry] Yes.

- I mean first impressions,
it looks like a chicken.
Like, there's nothing special.
There's no,

sometimes you can see there's
different colouring of the skin

or something like that. It
literally looks like a chicken.

- Should we eat it? Well, we
cook it first, then eat it.
- Oh, Jamie, it's like Sunday lunch.
- So in front of you,
you've got two dishes cook the same way.
Both slow roasted,

one is the potentially
pretentious ingredient,

and the other is a
relatively standard one,
but still good quality.
Start dishing up.
- Shall we do a bit of thigh, Jay?
I'll give you a bit of thigh.
It's worth pointing out,

the other one is still high
welfare and really good quality.
- We're just picking it up.

We're going in, we're
going in with the fingers!
- [Barry] You going in?

You're starting with the
potentially pretentious chicken.

The poultry's fed with the
food produced on the farm,

maize and wheat form
the basis of their diet,
with the addition of essential oils

and more than 25 wild plants
from this protected site.
These include dandelion,
heather, bramble, nettles, and horsetail.

These plants are all selected
for their tonic properties and

the farmer says they give a
much more organic flavour,
but what are you getting?
- I'm getting two very different textures.
- [Barry] Are you?
- From the two different chicken thighs.
- [Barry] Okay.

- In terms of dark meat, which
is what I've gone in with,

I would say that the
potentially pretentious one
is incredibly dark.

- So it turns out, two weeks
before their slaughter,

they are on a strict diet
of five different herbs.

And for the hens, they are
then also fed cows milk.

This creates a better distribution
of the fat throughout the
chicken, giving it a different texture.
- That,
feels crazy.
- This, the potentially pretentious one,
I feel it's almost like game meat.
It does taste incredible.

It's just not what we always
associate with chicken,

because we're so used to
this style of chicken.
- So if you were creating your ultimate
roast chicken dish for a bunch of mates,
what chicken would you go for?
- Easy answer, not that chicken.
- Standard chicken?
- I'd go standard chicken.

- The potentially pretentious
one is not bog standard.
It tastes incredible,

but it's texture puts in a
place where I think most people
would think twice about it.
- Let's talk money again.

So our standard high
welfare chicken, £8.30.
What are you thinking for the
potentially pretentious chicken.

- So I wouldn't think twice
about £8.30 for a chicken,
possibly pay a bit more.
Would I pay double or triple?
Three times the price 24, £25.20.
- I think that's £35.
(laughs)

- £55 for a single chicken
for a single chicken.
- In the 30 odd years on this planet.
- Why round down?
(laughs)
- In nearly 30 years I've lived!

I struggled to justify
that price for a chicken,
based on all preconceptions.
I just wonder if maybe that is part of
including the piguvian tax,
whereas that, already high welfare,

but is that just pushing the
price down the road to other

nutritional sustainable
environmental concerns and costs,
you know, in years to come?
- Is it pretentious?

- I'm not sure even all the
backstory of feeding on the

special tonic diet and the
milk fed chicken is something
I'm quite ready to jump on board with yet.
So it's very, very close to pretentious.
- Oh!
- Very, very close to pretentious.

- All of the talk about
eating special diets
and drinking milk in the last two weeks,

it just, that's bumf, and
therefore that's pretentious.
- Ooh! We got one! Finally,
we can now call this episode
a pretentious ingredient episode.
- It's about resetting the barometer
of what is normal to us,
and that's normal up until now,
and what perhaps normal should be.

And then probably more importantly
where you would use it.

Because I think most of
the ingredients today,

are stand out on their own,
but where would you use them?
Is it midweek?
- I think that's where we need your help.
Were any of these pretentious?

And what would you do with
them? Please comment down below.
Let us know.
We have an app, it's called Meal Packs,
and helps you plan and

then cook a week's worth
of meals using one set of
ingredients, saving you money,
cutting down on food waste,
and answering the age old question,
What should we have for dinner?
It's free to try for a whole month.
The link is in the description box below.

- No.
- No worries.
